Fabrication of hexagonal/cubic tungsten oxide homojunction with improved photocatalytic activity Yueqi Kong a Honggang Sun b ⁎ Xian Zhao a Baoyu Gao b Weiliu Fan c ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, Shandong University, Jinan 250100, China State Key Laboratory of Crystal Materials, Shandong University Jinan 250100 China b School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250100, China School of Environmental Science and Engineering, Shandong University Jinan 250100 China c School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University, Jinan, 250100, China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Shandong University Jinan 250100 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Tel.: +86 531 88366330; fax: +86 531 88364864. Graphical abstract A homojunction with different phases of tungsten oxide photocatalyst was prepared via a hydrothermal method by adjusting the pH value. The structural analysis showed the homojunction consisted of tungsten bronze-type (hexagonal) and pyrochlore-type (cubic) structures. The rod-like hexagonal phase inserted into block cubic phase to form a well-defined homojunction structure under the proper pH condition. The activity of photocatalyst was tested through degradating RhB and water oxidation. The results indicated the homojunction photocatalyst displayed a higher photocatalytic activity compared with individual tungsten oxide under visible light and full sunlight spectra irradiation. The further investigations revealed the inner electric filed at the interface of the homojunction facilitated the separation of electron-hole pairs, resulting in the improved photoelectrochemical performance. The design of favorable tungsten oxide homojunction structure in the present work provided a promising method for the development of other efficient photocatalysts. Keywords Tungsten oxide Homojunction Photocatalyst 1 Introduction Semiconductor photocatalysts have been intensively investigated in the last decades as it is potential in the applications to degradation of harmful pollutants and water splitting [1–3]. To further improve the photocatalytic activity, heterogeneous structures are considered as one of effective strategies to design new photocatalysts. Two major heterostructures, metal/semiconductor and semiconductor/semiconductor, are commonly applied in photocatalytic research [4–8]. Several factors are taken into consideration for an efficient heterojunction, such as proper material choice, surface properties, band structure matching and crystallinity of photocatalysts [9]. Recently, the homojunction constituted by the different phases of the same photocatalyst has attracted much attention for it is simple, controllable and usually of great photocatalytic activity [10–12]. Li and coworkers reported that an efficient homojunction formed between the anatase and rutile TiO2 nanoparticles could greatly enhance the photocatalytic activity for hydrogen production, suggesting that the enhanced photocatalytic activity was related to the efficient surface-phase junctions [13]. They also demonstrated another homojunction of α/β Ga2O3 and put forward that the promoted charge separation induced by the inner electric field between α and β Ga2O3 was the main reason for the improvement of photocatalytic activity [14]. Based on the matching band principle, Zhang's group selected the α-Bi2O3 and γ-Bi2O3 to build a α/γ Bi2O3 homojunction photocatalyst through a controllable synthesis method, which showed better activity in the degradation of RhB than that of single phase Bi2O3 [15]. Usai et al. reported the preparation of a highly active homostructured monoclinic/tetragonal-BiVO4 system by yttrium doping, which noted the presence of yttrium and the formation of monoclinic/tetragonal homostructure would suppress the recombination of charge carriers and lead to a higher photon efficiency [16]. From these reports, it can be seen that the homojunction has been proposed as one of the effective and promising strategies to improve the activity of photocatalysts. Tungsten oxide (including tungsten oxide hydrate), as a kind of n-type semiconductor material, has been intensively studied due to their good optical and electrical properties, and the potential applications in lithium batteries, electrochromic windows, gas sensors and photocatalysis [17–21]. Furthermore, the tungsten oxide-based materials appear some different crystal structures including tungsten bronze-type hexagonal, pyrochlore-type cubic and so on, which suggests a potential in constructing homojunction photocatalysts. In the previous studies, both tungsten bronze-type hexagonal phase and pyrochlore-type cubic phase have received attentions for application to photocatalyst and show a high activity for degrading pollution and splitting water [22–24]. It should be emphasized that the realization of efficient homojunction demands the energy structure match between two different phases, which has been used as the standard to constitute homojunction from a series of existing phases. In our work, the valence band spectra analysis indicates that the hexagonal and the cubic tungsten oxides are proper to constitute a homojunction. In the present work, a tungsten bronze-type hexagonal/pyrochlore-type cubic homojunction has been prepared via a one-step hydrothermal method with an appropriate pH condition. This homojunction photocatalyst greatly improves the photocatalytic activity for degrading RhB and producing oxygen from water oxidation compared with individual tungsten oxide. The mechanism of improved photocatalytic activity of homojunction is discussed in detail. The work can provide a promising approach for the development of efficient homojunction photocatalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of photocatalysts All reagents were of analytical grade and used as received without purification. The synthesis of photocatalysts was carried out using a facile manner via a hydrothermal method. In a typical procedure, 3.30g Na2WO4·2H2O and 5.85g NaCl were dissolved in 70mL deionized water, and the above solution was vigorously stirred for 10min. Then the pH values of the solution were adjusted to ∼1.5, ∼2.5 and ∼3.5 by drop-wise adding of concentrated HCl solution (11.8mol/L) under constant stirring. The resulting mixture was transferred into 100mL Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclave, sealed, and maintained at 453K for 24h. The products were collected by centrifugation and washed for three times with deionized water and ethanol, then dried at 333K for all night. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained on a D8 Advanced X-ray diffractometer (Bruker Germany), using Cu Kα radiation at a scan rate of 0.02° 2θ s−1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray emission was carried out by using an S-4800 field emission SEM (FESEM, Hitachi, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 5kV. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) analysis was conducted with the use of a JEM 2100 microscope at an accelerating voltage of 200kV. Ultraviolet visible (UV–vis) diffuse reflectance spectra were recorded using a UV–vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu UV-2550, Japan). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were performed on an ESCALAB 250 spectrometer equipped with an Al Kα source. All the binding energies were referenced to the C1s peak at 284.8eV of the surface adventitious carbon. Infrared absorption and Raman spectra were recorded by Thermo Nicolet NEXUS 670 FT-IR spectrophotometer. Nitrogen absorption isotherms were measured with an ASAP 2020 absorption analyzer at liquid nitrogen temperature. Prior to the measurements, the samples were degassed at a temperature of 77K for 10h. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area was determined from the relative pressure range of 0.05–0.3. The photoluminescence (PL) measurements were performed in a luminescence spectrophotometer (Hitachi F-4500) operate at room temperature with the excitation at 275nm. 2.3 Photocatalytic experiments The photocatalytic activities of the as-prepared samples were evaluated by decolorization of rhodamine B (RhB) under visible light irradiation from a 300W metal-halide lamp equipped with a 420nm cutoff filter. The 50mg photocatalyst of each experiment was dispersed into 50mL RhB (10mg/L) aqueous solution. Prior to light irradiation, the solution was continuously stirred in the dark for 0.5h to ensure the establishment of absorption-desorption equilibrium between the sample and RhB. At given time (30min) intervals, 5mL of each sample was taken, followed by centrifugation to remove the photocatalyst. The concentration of RhB was determined in terms of the change of optical absorption at 552nm during the photoreaction using a Hitachi U-3500 UV–vis spectrometer. Photocatalytic oxygen evolution was performed in a quartz reaction connected to a closed gas circulation system. A 300W Xe lamp was employed to simulate sunlight spectra. Both simulated visible light (λ >420nm) and full sunlight spectra are considered to test the activity of the as-prepared samples. In each run, 0.1g photocatalyst powder was suspended in 100mL water with a constant magnetic stirring. Prior to irradiation, the system was vacuumized to remove air completely. The evolution of oxygen was measured by using an on-line gas chromatography with thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.4 Photoelectrochemical measurements The photocurrents were carried out by an electrochemical workstation in a standard three electrode system, in which three electrodes were composed with the sample as the working electrode, a Pt foil as the counter electrode, and Ag/AgCl (saturated KCl) as the reference electrode. For the fabrication of the working electrode, samples were obtained by mixing 40mg of as-prepared powder and a certain amount of Nafion solution homogeneously. The samples were then spread on an indium-tin oxide (ITO) conducting glass by spin coater and dried at 373K for 1h. A 300W Xe lamp (PLS-SXE300C, Beijing Trusttech Co., Ltd) was used as the light source. The electrolyte was a 0.5M Na2SO4 aqueous solution. It was bubbled with nitrogen for 30min under vigorous stirring before measurement. The photocurrents with light on and off were measured at 0.5V. In the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements, the frequency was scanned from 0.01 to 100,000Hz at an applied under simulated sunlight irradiation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material's characterization The pH value is decisive for controlling the phase of the final resultant products in a hydrothermal process. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of three samples prepared by hydrothermal treatment at 453K for 24h under different pH values. For the pH value of 1.5, the XRD pattern of sample is in good agreement with the standard card of JCPDS no. 35-1001, which is assigned to tungsten bronze-type hexagonal WO3·0.33H2O. With increasing the pH value to 3.5, only pyrochlore-type cubic WO3·0.5H2O corresponded with the standard card of JCPDS no. 44-0363 is obtained. When the pH value is 2.5, the XRD peaks show a mixture of hexagonal WO3·0.33H2O and cubic WO3·0.5H2O. The phase composition for each phase is calculated according to the following formula [25]: hexagonal _ wt % = ∑ I h ∑ I h + ∑ I c , cubic _ wt % = 1 − hexagonal _ wt % . The calculated compositions of the mixed phases are 63wt% for the hexagonal WO3·0.33H2O and 37wt% for the cubic WO3·0.5H2O, respectively. The samples with different pH values of 1.5, 2.5 and 3.5 are denoted as h-WO3·0.33H2O, h/c-WO3·nH2O and c-WO3·0.5H2O in this paper. The XRD diffraction peaks of the three samples prepared via hydrothermal method are all narrow and sharp, showing their high crystallinity. The SEM is used to characterize the surface morphology of the as-prepared hexagonal, cubic, hexagonal/cubic samples. As is displayed in Fig. 2a and b, the h-WO3·0.33H2O mainly consists of nanorods with the length of 1–2μm and dimension of about 200nm, while the c-WO3·0.5H2O is uniformly made up of block-like nanoparticles of about 2–5μm in size. For the h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction, Fig. 2c and d show there are two kinds of nanoparticles in the sample, and some nanorods grow from the surface of block-like particles. The details can be clearly seen via HRTEM, as shown in Fig. 2e, the nanorods insert into the block-like particles, forming a hedgehog-like structure. Moreover, a selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern reveals that the rod is hexagonal phase with the <001> growth direction (inset of Fig. 2f) [23]. The more detailed SAED pattern as shown in Supporting Information (Figure SI1) supports that a compact homojunction consisted of hexagonal and cubic phases is achieved via a one-step hydrothermal method. FT-IR and Raman spectra are measured to show more detailed structures of the three samples. For the IR spectra, as shown in Fig. 3a, the broad bands at 600–900cm−1 and 3500∼3700cm−1 are assigned to the W-O-W stretching mode, and the O-H stretching mode of physical absorbed water, respectively. The IR absorption peaks at about 970cm−1 and 1600cm−1 are associated with the O-H bending mode and WO stretching mode [26,27], respectively, which are both induced by the crystal water. Raman measurements shown in Fig. 3b are consistent with the above observations. The Raman shift of around 800cm−1 is assigned to W–O–W stretching mode. The peaks above 900cm−1 are corresponding to WO stretching mode, which is the characteristic of tungsten oxide hydrates. The bands below 500cm−1 are correlated to the whole lattice vibrations [28,29]. The broader bands for the h-WO3·0.33H2O and h/c-WO3·nH2O samples should be due to the smaller crystal size than c-WO3·nH2O sample, which is consistent with the result of SEM. XPS is performed to analyze the surface and near-surface chemical state for the as-prepared samples. The whole XPS survey scans (as shown in Figure SI2) show that all the samples contain not only W and O elements, but also Na and trace amounts of C1s. The peak for C1s at 284.8eV is originated from the adventitious hydrocarbon in the XPS instrument itself. In addition to C1s, a relatively weak signal of Na (centered at 1071.7, 1071.7 and 1071.8eV respectively) is also observed on the surface of each sample shown by NaKll peak. In general, the stable phases of tungsten oxide at ambient temperature are monoclinic and orthorhombic. To maintain the stability of hexagonal and cubic tungsten oxide, some impurities, such as some resident ions or/and molecules, are considered as requisite in the lattice channel to prevent thermodynamic transformation from the metastable phases to stable monoclinic phases [30–34]. Szilagyi et al. noted that the Na+ cation in the lattice channel is necessary to stabilize the crystal structure of WO3·nH2O during a common hydrothermal preparation process [35]. Surface chemical compositions listed in Table 1 give the W/O atom ratio of about 0.4 for the three samples, which shows a nonstoichiometric tungsten oxide with some oxygen vacancies. The vacancy will reduce oxidation state of W cations to form reduced centers in the surface of photocatalysts, which can act active sites for photocatalysis. Fig. 4 shows the W4f and O1s core level spectra obtained by region scans. As shown in Fig. 4, the W4f spectra for each sample can be deconvoluted into two doublets. The first doublet of the three samples gives the W4f7/2 at 35.94, 35.75, and 35.81eV, and the W4f5/2 at 38.10, 37.90, and 37.94eV, which are assigned to the W6+ oxidation state. The second doublet with relatively weak intensity show the W4f7/2 at 35.64, 35.45, and 35.45eV and the W4f5/2 at 37.75, 37.55, and 37.53eV, which are associated with the W5+ oxidation state. The calculated ratio of W5+/W6+ is about 4%. The O1s XPS of each sample mainly consist of two components. The two peaks were also observed in other experiments [36–38]. The peak with lower bind energy (less than 529.7eV in CeO2, 529.6eV in N-TiO2) was ascribed to the lattice oxygen. The peak with higher bind energy (less than 532.0eV in CeO2, 533.3eV in N-TiO2) was ascribed to oxygen vacancy and/or OH/NOx group adsorbed on the vacancy sites. Therefore, in the present work the main peak at about 530.5eV is also assigned to the lattice oxygen in tungsten oxide. However, the prepared WO3 samples accompany with crystal water, thus the relatively smaller peak at more than 532.2eV is originated from both oxygen vacancy and the residual water. This is also agreement with the observation in tungsten oxide nanowires reported by Yong's work [39]. The UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy of as-prepared samples is shown in Fig. 5 . The absorption edges (λ ab) for h-WO3·0.33H2O, h/c-WO3·nH2O, and c-WO3·0.5H2O are about 450, 430, and 375nm, respectively. There is weak tailed adsorption in more than 500nm region. Parida et al. and Singh et al. noted the adsorption should be due to the effect of lattice defect [40,41]. As the discussion of XPS results, there are few oxygen vacancies in the samples. Therefore, the weak tailed adsorption is attributed to the effect of oxygen vacancy. Fig. 6a shows the photocatalytic performance of the three photocatalysts by degradation of RhB under visible light irradiation (λ >420nm), and the blank experiment is also listed as reference. According to kt =−ln(C/C 0), the photocatalytic degradation rate of RhB is calculated and shown in Table 1. The c-WO3·0.5H2O sample shows almost no degradation performance in that it cannot be excited by visible light due to its wide bandgap. It also can be seen that the h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction shows a higher activity of RhB degradation than that of h-WO3·0.33H2O. The stability and reusability of as-prepared h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction photocatalyst was evaluated by recycled photodegradation experiment of RhB. After each photodegradation cycle, the photocatalyst is collected by centrifugation, washed and dried for 6hours. The residual photocatalyst is reused in the next photodegradation cycle, then added a balanced amount of new h/c-WO3·nH2O powder to maintain the same photodedradation experimental condition. As shown in Fig. 6b, the h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction photocatalyst shows good stability and reusability for visible light degradation of RhB and no obvious activity loss is found after three recycles. It is well known that RhB is a colored dye which mainly absorbs visible light of wavelength 552nm, and the as-prepared h/c-WO3·H2O can only absorb light of wavelength shorter than 430nm. Therefore, the degradation process may be driven by the photosensitization of RhB under visible light irradiation (λ >420nm) [42,43]. In order to avoid the photosensitization effect of RhB, we further explored water oxidation experiments using different irradiation conditions to clarify the intrinsic photocatalysis of h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction. Fig. 7a and b show the time courses of oxygen evolution for h-WO3·0.33H2O, c-WO3·0.5H2O and h/c-WO3·nH2O samples under different irradiation conditions (visible light and simulated sunlight). It is obvious that the h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction exhibits a significantly enhanced performance compared with the individual phases in both light conditions. The average oxygen evolution rates are calculated to be 1.1 and 10.56μmol/h, respectively. All the representative results are tabulated in Table 1. The higher activity of h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction than that of h-WO3·0.33H2O is also in agreement with the test of dedradation of RhB under visible light. Consequently, the homojunction will be good for improving the visible light activity of tungsten oxide photocatalysts. In the following section, we will further focus on the mechanism discussion in order to clarify the photocatalysis. 3.2 Mechanism's discussion The mechanism of the enhanced visible light activity of h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction will be discussed in this section. It is well known that the performance of semiconductor photocatalysts refers to many body effects. A significant issue influencing the photocatalytic activity is the surface area. In general, a larger surface area yields more absorption and reaction sites, which may promote photocatalytic rate. The BET surface areas of h-WO3·0.33H2O, c-WO3·0.5H2O and h/c-WO3·nH2O are measured to be 23, 2 and 11m2/g, respectively, as listed in Table 1, which is in agreement with the size of each sample in SEM. Obviously, the result suggests that the surface area is not responsible for the enhanced performance in the h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction. The higher amounts of crystal water have a positive effect on many semiconductor/solvent interfaces. In order to study the effect of crystal water of as-prepared tungsten oxides on their photodegradation and water oxidaton properties, dehydration through annealing treatment at 473K for 10h is carried out for h-WO3·0.33H2O, c-WO3·0.5H2O and h/c-WO3·nH2O photocatalysts, which is based on the work of Chen and co-workers [43]. The XRD patterns of the three dehydrated samples (as shown in Figure S3) exhibit the peaks shift to a higher 2θ value due to the smaller lattice spacing after the loss of crystal water. It is found that the dehydrated WO3 are barely active. Moreover, the crystal water is added back to the dehydrated samples in a hydrothermal process [44], and the XRD patterns are similar to the original samples. The rehydrated samples show similar photocatalytic activities to the original photocatalysts. Therefore, we conclude more crystal water is one of the reason that h/c-WO3·nH2O shows a better active than h-WO3·0.33H2O. The extremely high activity of homojunction implies that the intrinsic photoelectrochemical performance of the h/c-WO3·nH2O may be markedly improved. Photocurrent measurements have been thus carried out to understand the changes of the photoelectrochemical property of h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction. As shown in Fig. 7c and d, the photocurrent response of h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction is much higher than that of individual h-WO3·0.33H2O under both visible light and simulated sunlight irradiations. It is clearly that the improvement of photoelectrochemical performance of homojunction is consistent with the higher activity of h/c-WO3·nH2O. To further reveal the mechanism of the improvement of photoelectrochemical performance of the homojunction, the more detailed analysis for h-WO3·0.33H2O, h/c-WO3·nH2O, and c-WO3·0.5H2O is implemented according to the equation as followed [45]: I = n q μ F A where q is the electronic charge, F and A are the electric field and cross-sectional area, respectively. Here, F and A are the same for the three samples. Therefore, the photocurrent response should be decided by the density (n) and mobility (μ) of the charge carrier in semiconductor photocatalyst. Two factors affect the charge carrier density (n) of the photocatalyst. One is relevant to the capability of the photon absorption of the photocatalyst, which determines the number of excited electrons. As shown in the UV–vis spectra (Fig. 5), it is clearly that the h-WO3 with an adsorption edge of 450nm has a large light response region, while the c-WO3 with an adsorption edge of 375nm is only excited by UV light. Therefore, the hexagonal phase is responsible for accepting the photons to motivate electrons when the h/c-WO3 is irradiated under visible light. Namely, the hexagonal phase acts as sensitizer in the h/c-WO3. Although the capability of the photon absorption of h-WO3·0.33H2O is better than that of h/c-WO3·nH2O, the photocurrent response and photocatalytic activity of h/c-WO3·nH2O are much higher than that of h-WO3·0.33H2O. The PL spectra (Fig. 8a) give more information of the photocatalysts. The peaks at about 450nm of the tungsten oxide are attributed to the recombination of electron-hole pairs and recombining through band-band transitions [46] . The lower PL efficiency of the homojunction suggests the lower electron-hole recombination rate. As it is known, the inner electric field formed at the interface of semiconductor-junction will suppress carrier's recombination by guiding the different preferred migration directions of the photo-generated electrons and holes [47]. The XPS valence band spectra are measured and shown in Fig. 9 for analyzing the valence band positions of as-prepared samples. Based on the results of the valence band spectra and the calculated band gap, the schematic diagram of the homojunction band configuration of is plotted. It is clearly that an effective inner electric field is built between hexagonal and cubic phases. Moreover, the built-inner electric field will facilitate that the photogenerated electrons continuously transfer from hexagonal phase to cubic phase and the holes transfer inversely. Thus, the homojunction greatly promote the carriers’ separation, resulting in the improved photoelectrochemical performance. Therefore, the h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction provides a successful method to improve the carrier density (n) by suppressing the carrier's recombination rate. As mentioned above, the photocurrent response is also affected by the carriers’ mobility (μ) of photocatalysts. According to μ = qτ/m *, the mobility of charge carrier is related to the carrier's mean free time (τ) and effective mass (m * ). The emission peaks of PL spectra from 460 to 500nm correspond to the present of defects and/or impurities [48,49] . As shown in Fig. 9a, obviously, the h-WO3·0.33H2O has more defects than that in c-WO3·0.5H2O, which suggests larger carrier's mean free time (τ) in c-WO3·0.5H2O. For the n-type tungsten oxide semiconductor, the electrons are majority carriers and electronic effective mass (m e *) decides the carriers’ mobility. First-principle theory calculations are performed to achieve the band structures of hexagonal and cubic phases to calculate the electron effective mass (SI5). Base on the calculated results, the electron effective mass of hexagonal and cubic phases are about 0.091 and 0.039, respectively. PL spectra and theoretical calculations indicate that the cubic phase has a better electronic mobility. Moreover, to back up our PL spectra and theoretical calculations, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements are supplemented to illustrate the electronic mobility and conductivity of the three samples. Fig. 8b shows the EIS response of the three samples with simulated sunlight irradiation, which gives a smaller arc radius for c-WO3·0.5H2O than that of both h-WO3·0.33H2O and h/c-WO3·nH2O. This result indicates that the cubic phase has a better electron's mobility, which is agreement with the results of PL spectra and theoretical calculations. Therefore, the introduction of the cubic phase will be helpful for improving photoelectrochemical performance of the homojunction. In summary, the high visible light activity of h/c-WO3·nH2O homojunction should be originated from (a) the more crystal water in the lattice channels, (b) the good ability to visible light absorption of hexagonal phase, (c) the appropriate energy level matching to promote electron-hole separation, and (d) the good electronic mobility of cubic phase. 4 Conclusion Tungsten bronze-type hexagonal and pyrochlore-type cubic tungsten oxides are synthesized and used to constitute a homojunction via a hydrothermal method. The homojunction performs higher photocatalytic activities for both RhB degradation and oxygen production than those of individual photocatalyst under visible light irradiation. The mechanism of improved visible light activity of the homojunction is discussed in detail. Our results suggest that the harvest of visible light, the energy level matching, and the carriers’ transport rate are all important for improving photocatalytic active. The present work will open a new strategy for developing efficient homojunction photocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: A homojunction with different phases of tungsten oxide photocatalyst was prepared via a hydrothermal method by adjusting the pH value. The structural analysis showed the homojunction consisted of tungsten bronze-type (hexagonal) and pyrochlore-type (cubic) structures. The rod-like hexagonal phase inserted into block cubic phase to form a well-defined homojunction structure under the proper pH condition. The activity of photocatalyst was tested through degradating RhB and water oxidation. The results indicated the homojunction photocatalyst displayed a higher photocatalytic activity compared with individual tungsten oxide under visible light and full sunlight spectra irradiation. The further investigations revealed the inner electric filed at the interface of the homojunction facilitated the separation of electron-hole pairs, resulting in the improved photoelectrochemical performance. The design of favorable tungsten oxide homojunction structure in the present work provided a promising method for the development of other efficient photocatalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Fabrication of hexagonal/cubic tungsten oxide homojunction with improved photocatalytic activity
